todos.title: Law of Shitty Click Throughs
todos.body: Over time all marketing channels get saturated.  Past tactics may become crowded and ineffective.

todos.title: Email Marketing Software
todos.body: customer.io, MailChimp, Constant Contact

todos.title: Hypercompetitive Market
todos.body: You build something people want but a lot of other companies are building it too so it is tough to get customers to pay good margins.

todos.title: Existing Platforms
todos.body: Web sites or apps with huge numbers of users that you can plug into.

todos.title: Validation through Search Engine Marketing
todos.body: Validating your product through messaging and keywords you use in AdWords.

todos.title: Underutilized Channels
todos.body: Usually the most underutilized traction channels are the most promising ones.

todos.title: Feeder Sites
todos.body: Use feeder sites to test your message before your product is complete.

todos.title: Standard Partnership
todos.body: Two companies work together to make one or both of their products better.  Ex. Apple/Nike.

todos.title: Joint Ventures
todos.body: Two companies work together to create an entirely new product or venture.

todos.title: Offline Ads
todos.body: TV, radio, billboards, infomecials, newspaper, magazine, flyers.

todos.title: Publicity
todos.body: Traditional media outlets.  Start small.  Large outlets get news and pickup stories from smaller outlets.  Reach out to reporters to tell them about your articles.  Use sites like HARO (Help a Reporter Out).  Submit story to link sharing sites (reddit, Hacker News).  Share story on social networks.  Email story to influencers.  Ping blogs about your story.

todos.title: No Real Market
todos.body: They want it but won’t pay enough for it to cover the bills.

todos.title: Narrow Market
todos.body: They want it but there are not enough customers to reach profitability.

todos.title: Targeting Blogs
todos.body: Target blogs and join their conversation through promotion of your product.  Worked for Codeacademy, Mint, and reddit.

todos.title: Startup Success
todos.body: Startups don’t just take off, their founders make them take off.  They have to recruit users manually.  They can’t wait for users to come to them, they have to go out and get them.

todos.title: Dropbox Example
todos.body: Started marketing with search engine marketing but were spending $230 to acquire a $99 customer.  They switched to viral marketing, using a built-in referral program.

todos.title: 50 Percent Rule
todos.body: Spend 50% of the time on product and 50% of the time on traction.  The biggest mistakes startups make is failing to pursue traction in parallel with product development.

todos.title: Offline Events
todos.body: Small meetups to large conferences.  Particularly effective for startups with long sales cycles.

todos.title: Infographics
todos.body: Shared 20 times more than articles.

todos.title: Milestones
todos.body: Set milestones to achieve your traction goals.  They need not be the same metrics as the goal but help lead towards the goal.

todos.title: Finding Blogs
todos.body: Search “top blogs for x”, search on YouTube and find influencers that create videos, delicious website, twitter, social mention site, ask around.

todos.title: Coupon Sites
todos.body: RetailMeNot, CouponCabin, Brad’s Deals, SlickDeals offer discounts to visitors.

todos.title: Hard to Reach Market
todos.body: Reaching people is cost prohibitive, you have an inexpensive product that requires a direct sales force to sell.

todos.title: Cost Per Point
todos.body: Radio ads are priced at a cost to reach 1 percent of the radio station’s listeners.

todos.title: Microsites
todos.body: Put them on their own domain.

todos.title: Unconventional PR
todos.body: Publicity stunts and customer appreciation (holding contests, sending handwritten notes).  Must be bold, edgy, buck the system, bend the rules (without breaking them).

todos.title: Direct Mail Advice
todos.body: Provide self addressed envelope, hand write envelopes, have a clear action you want them to take.

todos.title: Marketing Process
todos.body: Promote a purpose, sell a process, make money from the accompanying technology and support.

todos.title: Guest Posting
todos.body: Posting on other site’s blogs.

todos.title: Content Marketing
todos.body: Posting lots of content, usually via blogs.  After every post, ping influencers for feedback.  Engage with customers by writing useful answers on targeted forums like Quora.  If you blog, dedicate atleast 6 months to it.

todos.title: Fat Head Keyword
todos.body: Popular searches that directly describe your company.

todos.title: Click Through Rate
todos.body: Percentage of ad impressions that result in clicks to your site.

todos.title: Affiliate Programs
todos.body: Pay people or companies for making a sale or getting a lead.  See ClickBAnk, Pepperjam affiliate network, Commission Junction, Pepperjam, LinkShare, ShareASale, Affiliate.com, Adknowledge, MobAff, Neverblue, Clickbooth, RetailMeNot.

todos.title: Search Engine Marketing
todos.body: Paid search, pay per click.

todos.title: Conversion Pages
todos.body: Pages that prospective customers land on from invitations.  These pages work best when they have the same messaging as the invitations that preceded them.

todos.title: AB Testing Software
todos.body: Optimizely, Visual Website Optimizer, Unbounce.

todos.title: Optimization v. Testing
todos.body: Optimization is running expensive ads and tuning their performance.  Testing is running a small amount of cheap tests that give some indication of how successful a given channel strategy will be.

todos.title: Trade Shows
todos.body: Opportunity to showcase your products in person.  Opportunity to get in touch with editors of magazines, bloggers, customers, vendors, competition, partners.

todos.title: Analyzing Competitor SEO
todos.body: Open Site Explorer, Google Trends, Alexa Search Rank, Followerwonk.

todos.title: First 10
todos.body: Only about 10% of clicks occur beyond the first ten results.

todos.title: Distribution Deals
todos.body: One party provides a product or services in exchange for access to potential customers.

todos.title: Licensing
todos.body: One company has a strong brand that an upstart wats to use in a new product or service.

todos.title: Conversion Percentage
todos.body: Number of customers who when they visit your site make a purchase.

todos.title: Two Biggest Traction Mistakes
todos.body: Not having a concrete traction goal and believing that what has worked in the past will also work in the future.

todos.title: Aggregators
todos.body: Nextag, PriceGrabber aggregate products from retailers and add things like ratings, reviews, comparisons.

todos.title: Distribution Failure
todos.body: Most companies try many distribution/marketing channels and none of them work.  The best companies strategically pick one and if that doesn’t work are lucky to pivot to one or two other ones.

todos.title: Traction Goal
todos.body: Metrics to become profitable or get funding.  Ex. One thousand paying customers, one hundred new daily customers, 10% of your market.

todos.title: Email Marketing
todos.body: Marketing via email messaging.  Avoid large bulk unsolicited emails.  Require an email to access premium content, such as videos or white papers.  Email marketing can be very useful to retain customers and bring them back to your site.  Avoid noreply emails.

todos.title: Search Engine Optimization (SEO)
todos.body: Making sure your website shows up for key search results.  Don’t’ buy in-links.

todos.title: Share and Embed
todos.body: Make things really easy to share and embed the way that the user will want to share and embed (ie. Sending a link, email messaging, etc.).

todos.title: Major Social Media
todos.body: LinkedIn, Twitter, Facebook, StumbleUpon, Foursquare, Tumbler, reddit, YouTube, BuzzFeed, Scribd, SlideShare, Pinterest, Instagram, SnapChat.

todos.title: Long-Tail Keyword
todos.body: Less popular and more specific searches.

todos.title: Billboard Companies
todos.body: Lamar, Lear Channel, Outfront Media.

todos.title: Tracking Results
todos.body: Keep track of all test results on a quant-based marketing spreadsheet. Include channel strategies, how many customers are available (traffic), click through rates (CTR), conversion rate (sign up for your product), cost to acquire customer, and lifetime value of customer.

todos.title: Viral Coefficient
todos.body: K = New invites * (new customers/new invites)

todos.title: Testing
todos.body: It’s impossible to predict which channels will work until you test them.

todos.title: Offline Tracking
todos.body: Is difficult.  Consider sending people to different landing pages or phone numbers to help the tracking process.

todos.title: Community Building
todos.body: Investing in the connections among your customers and fostering relationships.

todos.title: Lead Qualification
todos.body: Improve conversion by qualifying the lead.  Put lead qualification in CRM.

todos.title: Bullseye Brainstorming
todos.body: Identify every single possible traction channel.    Ask how much will it cost to acquire customers through this channel, how many customers are available, are the customers you get through this channel the kind you want.

todos.title: Vertical Sites
todos.body: Hundreds of sites that have amassed significant audiences for a specific vertical such as parenting, sports, electronics.

todos.title: Cost Per Acquisition
todos.body: How much it costs you to acquire a customer, not just a click.  Cost to by a click divided by the number of people that make a make a purchase after visiting your site.      Geaneology.com spent thousands of dollar driving people to landing pages with completely different messages.

todos.title: Supply Partnerships
todos.body: Help secure key inputs.

todos.title: Sales
todos.body: Hand holding prospects.

todos.title: Marketo Example
todos.body: Had SEO and blog in place before they even began product development.

todos.title: Key Goal for Startup
todos.body: Growth.  Not funding, technology advancements, exits, etc.

todos.title: Speaking Engagements
todos.body: Give free talks to local groups.  Record and post speaking engagement online.  Ask people to promote your event while you have their attention.  Give audience a call to action at the end of each event.

todos.title: Viral Marketing
todos.body: Getting existing customers to refer others to your product.  Invite other people to join your network.  Embed virality into communications with “get a free… button on your email or site.”  Embed buttons and widgets.  Copy someone else’s viral loop until you can get yours to start working.

todos.title: Core Channel
todos.body: Focus solely on the channel that will move the needle for your startup.  Other channels should simply serve to feed into your main distribution channel.

todos.title: SEM Strategy
todos.body: Find high potential keywords, group them into ads, test ad copy with landing pages.  Google Adwords, Bing Ads.  Google’s Keyword Planner, Keyword Spy, SEMrush, SpyFu.  Don’t expect your campaign to be profitable right away.  If your campaign breaks even after a short period of time you have a promising strategy.  Use Google Analytics URL Builder to create unique URLS.  Average click through rate for AdWords is 2% with 1.5% or less receiving a low quality score from Google.  Google search network, Google content network, Google Conversion Optimizer.

todos.title: Business Development
todos.body: Exchanging value through partnerships.  Create an exhaustive list of all your possible partnerships, send to your investors and key influencers to get introductions.  Target the person at the partner company who is in charge of the metrics that you can help improve.  Create a one-page term sheet.

todos.title: Email Referral
todos.body: Dropbox gives free space to any user who emails a friend encouraging dropbox and that person signs up.

todos.title: Calling on the Right Level
todos.body: Don’t start calling at the top unless you are working with small businesses.  Make sure you speak to people who have been around a long time and are empowered to help make decisions.  Lookout for “yes” people that won’t challenge their bosses but just go with the flow.

todos.title: Test Slowly
todos.body: Don’t prematurely scale your marketing channel until you have tested your channel and know that it is the right fit.

todos.title: Magazines
todos.body: Consider magazines that you yourself would never read.

todos.title: Analytics Tools
todos.body: Clicky, Mixpanel, Chartbeat.

todos.title: SPIN Selling
todos.body: Clarify the prospect is a potential customer by breaking the ice (situational question).  Get them talking about the problem.  Uncover all the implications of this problem.  Focus on how your solution solves the problem.

todos.title: Engineering as Marketing
todos.body: Calculators, widgets, educational microsites.  Ex.  Hubspots website grader, turned a service into a widget to drive traffic.  They provide something of true value for free, with no strings attached.  Make the offer extremely relevant to your business.  Demonstrate the value as quickly as possible. Make the most valuable thing free and the most necessary thing at cost.

todos.title: Four Common Pitfalls of Traction
todos.body: Building Something People Want Does Not Guarantee Success.  The four main pitfalls are no real market, too narrow market, hard to reach market, hypercompetitive market.

todos.title: Customer Appreciation
todos.body: Be awesome to your customers.  Give them free stuff.  Connect them to other people.  Go over and above.

todos.title: Social and Display Ads
todos.body: Banner ads on websites.  Often used for brand awareness.  Largest display networks are Google’s Display Network (Google content network), Advertising.com, Tribal Fusion, Conversant, Adblade, BuySellAds.  Check out MixRank or Adbeeat to see ads your competitors are running and where they place them.  Social media clients convert and stick at a much higher rate than non social media leads.

todos.title: Traction Bias
todos.body: Avoiding channels that you don’t like but could be the best for your customers.

todos.title: Ad Kit
todos.body: Audience prospectus that illustrates the audience demographic for a marketing channel.

todos.title: Priority Access Referral
todos.body: Asking people on its prelaunch waiting list to recommend product to their friends in return for priority product access.

todos.title: Role of Marketing & Sales
todos.body: Arm & Aim.  Marketing should arm the sales people with all the collateral they need to effectively win sales campaigns.  This includes presentation, ROI calculators, competitive analysis, etc.  To help sales reps figure out which target customers they should focus on.

todos.title: Cost Per Click
todos.body: Amount it costs to buy a click on an advertisement.

todos.title: Email Lists
todos.body: Affiliates have large email lists that they will recommend products to.

todos.title: Retargeting Sites
todos.body: AdRoll, Perfect Audience.

todos.title: Remnant Advertising
todos.body: Ad space that is currently being unused.  Manhattan Media or Novus Media specializes in these ad placements.

todos.title: Traction
todos.body: A sign that your company is taking off.

todos.title: ABC Deals
todos.body: A deals can close in the next three months, B deals within 12 months and C deals longer than 12 months.

todos.title: Loyalty Programs;  Upromise and ebates have reward programs for cash back and prizes on affiliate networks.
